Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		 A:united states<n><n><n><n>### Input<n><n><blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="und" dir="ltr">What is the first country to get the most death records when <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/coronavirus?src=hash&amp;ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">#coronavirus</a> is contained?<a href="https://t.co/QkWx0jjJF3">https://t.co\/QkWx0qkx6q</a></p>&mdash; Brianna Wiest (@briannawiest) <a href="https:<n>"https://twitter.com/_/"target="_blank">March 19, 2020</a></blockquote><n><script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><n><n>#### Question: <n>*  According to this tweet, what is the first country to die from "Coronavirus" when it is contained?<n><n>#### Answer: E:oceans<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately answers the question.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n>### Citation:https://leetcode.com/problems/best-time-to-buy-and-sell-stock/submissions/<n><n>### Instructions:Write a statement that correctly answers the question.<n><n>## Citation:https://education.illinois.edu/southwest/resources/homework/assignment_11.html<n><n>### Input :  A: How many coins will you get if you collect coins with total value 9? Choices: 0,1,2,3 B: No C: Yes<n><n>```python<n>A: 1<n>B: 2<n>C: 3<n>```<n><n>### Instuction: <n>The above problem was a tetris game type problem where the player could get score by adding numbers in his coin collection adding to any digits in the tetris 9. If he gets to 9, he gets another. It is equivalent to being able to choose the last 9 from any of the coin collection of 0s, 1s. 10s, 20s, 30s and 40s that he needs to score by.<n><n>### Input2: <n>A: This is an example of a binary problem of choice. There are only 4 different choices the player can make. But because there is only one option on each coin, there are only 4 ways to choose 9 from the collection. Because of this, there would be 4 different combinations of the numbers he scores by.<n><n>4 + 4 = 8

If it is a plural or possessive, etc., noun, the answer must be the right form. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What might be the result of a season of successful skiing? Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Select the choice that best answers the input.<n><n>* A<n>* B<n>* C<n>* D<n>* E<n><n>### Input:(1) How many years has Sam had his car since it was new? (2) How old is Sam’s car?<n><n>#### Sam has his car, which is a year old. His car was new for one year, meaning it was two years old when he purchased it. He now owns the car for two years which is equal to five years.<n><n>### Input The following sentences are examples of a parallel structure:<n>* “Mary had a little lamb, its fleece was white as snow. It stayed behind her and ate the rice she took to Mary.’-T. S. Eliot<n>* “We have eaten the past, we feed on the future. The future feeds on the eternal, the eternal feeds on the past, the past feeds on the present, and the present feeds on the future. -John Berger<n><n>#### What is the difference between “we feed on the future” and “the future feeds on the past”? Explain with specific reasons to justify your answer.<n><n>#### The order of the clauses is the difference. The clause with the same subject "we" is placed in the order we would commonly use in a sentence.<n>In “we feed on the ____________", the verb is placed after the subject, while the clause "_____________ feeds on the past" places the verb in the correct order (the subject comes before the verb).<n><n>### The following sentences are examples that do not express parallel structure:<n>* Mary had a pet dog and a pet cat.<n>* Mary had a little lamb whose fleece was white.<n><n>#### What is wrong with the sentences above? Suggest a change to avoid parallel errors in each sentence.<n><n>#### The second and third sentences do not contain the same amount of _________. Therefore, they do not express parallel structure.  <n>For the second sentence the lack of equality in the words "dog" and "cat" indicates they are not parallel.<n>For the third sentence, the "lamb" is plural, while the "whose" is singular.<n><n>#### Mary had a pet dog. Mary had a pet cat. (no error<n><n>#### Mary had as pet a dog. Mary had a

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Jim enjoyed killing people, but he did it too often and the cops found out.  What might the cops do to him? Choices:  A: going to jail B: going to prison C: beat him up D: get arrested E: die<n><n>### Response:		The Cops will pick "A" A: go to jail<n>B: go to prison<n><n>### Rationales: He enjoyed killing people, then the cops caught him. "going to jail" and "going to prison" means that the cops will not beat Jim or get arrested.<n><n>```<n><n><n># R1 29586403 -2817512<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>##Input:<n>During the day, Sarah did five hours and 45 minutes of homework. Sarah also went to the library for 2 hours and 12 minutes to do homework. How long did she spend on homework during the day?<n>```<n><n>###Response 29587028 : Sarah spent a total of 4 hours and 57 minutes (+54 mins) on homework during the<n>day.<n><n>###Rationales:<n>-54 mins is the total time she spent doing homework at the library (12mins x 5times/day).<n>Sarah's total homework time (time she spent doing her homework at home + the time she spent at the library) added together = <<5+12>>17mins(+54mins)= 71mins. Sarah did homework for 5hours and 45 minutes.<n><n>-54 mts is the extra time Sarah spent doing homework at home (12 minutes multiplied by 5 times/day).<n>The total time Sarah spent doing home works was 5hours and  45 mins added together.(5hours 45mins)<n><n>### Answer: Sarah spent a total of  4 hours and 5 minutes on homework during the <n>day.<n><n>```<n># R2 5974409 - 2661077<n>```<n><n>## Instructions:Write a response that completes the task.<n><n>### Input<n>Jim enjoyed killing people but he did it tooo often and the cops freaked out. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What is a grumpy person likely to have? Choices:  A: headache B: understand themselves C: compliments D: own house E: happiness<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is option D: own house. A grumpy person is likely to have a headache so option A: headache is incorrect.<n>A grumpy person does not understand themselves so option B: understand themselves is incorrect.<n>A compliment is a nice thing that someone might do or say if they have a great relationship with another person so option C: compliments is incorrect.<n>Finally you cannot have happiness unless someone else knows you so option E: happiness is incorrect.<n>Hence, the required option is option D: own a grumpy person's own house.<n><n>### Input:{input: The largest number I've ever seen is<n>7994. I<n>think that's a bigger number than<n>the biggest number you've ever seen.}Choices:<n>A: 1 B: 10 C: 100 D: 1000 E: 10,000<n><n>### Rationales:<n>A: The provided answer is option A: 1. The smallest number I've ever<n>seen is 1, the same as option 1.<n>Since the largest number is 7994, 1 is not even close to it. 7994 has more than 10 times more<n>significant digits.<n><n>B: The provided answer is is option B: 10.<n>Since the largest<n>number is 7993 the provided<n>answer is greater than 10 times larger.<n><n>C: The provided answer is not option C: 10, since<n>7994 is greater than 1,000.<n><n>D: The largest number has more than 1,085 times more<n>significants digits so option D: 10, is not<n>correct.<n>E: Since 7994 is not even close to 10,095 or<n>even 100,095 option E: 100,95 is incorrect.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer:10<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a response that appropriately replies to the below message.<n><n>### Message:<n>Hi,I found out about [a site called Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/).<n>You should check it out! <n>They are all
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where could a fungus grow and not be disturbed by sunlight? When you use the point slope form, you would have that equation in one form. However, what you have to do is find m and b by plugging in x1 in this equation, x =2, and y=2.2. Now let's plug this in.<n>You want the constant term at the end, so the first thing you need to do is subtract the y value from the y1. In this case, it is 2.2-2=-0.2. Therefor, m = -0.2. The last thing you have to do is change one of the x values into mx value. Since this is in mx, you would have mx into 1. You would have 1.2. Now you want to have your mx for one coordinate point, and one for each point. Therefore, you plug -0.2 and 1.0 into that and now you should have mx of 0.8 and the constant.

They also cannot lean against a wall because the chair might fall off or become a tripping hazard.<n><n>We are asked to explain how to place folding chairs where we do not plan to use them. We would put it in a closet. A closet has a door that we can open to store the chair or fold it into.<n><n>### Response<n><n>I would put a folded chair beside the beach because it will be close to where it is needed.<n><n>### Rationale: Close to where it is needed<n><n>-  We are told to put the chair close to where it is used.<n>-  The chair will be used in the beach and it will be close if the chair were put beside the beach. Choice: A triangle B square C rectangle<n><n>### Raitonales - Demonstration - Input Demonstration<n>---  Demonstration<n>We can see that the fold is in a square shape in the picture. We can see the large fold that makes the chairs stackable, but it is in the triangle shape. The small fold, is a small square that makes the chairs fold and unfold easily. Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		<n>- I would use the answer choice “D.” In this situation, because the dog is in a small apartment and it is only using part of the house then it seems like the dog has all the space it needs if it is only in one room.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>- If this was a dog out in the park then then the dog would likely feel like it has all the space in the word when it is being in the large, green grassy area. The point with the example is that the dog was inside rather than outside.<n>- I know that dogs often feel like they have all the space in the room or house that they are living in if they only go in one room, this is why I choose option “D” because it makes sense that in a small apartment the dog feels this way, even though he/she may be indoors.<n>- If the dog was outside in the dog park then it seems to have more space and room to walk and play than if it were just inside of a small apartment.<n>- If this were a dog in the living room then, it seems like it would only feel like having all the space it needed if another dog came to sit with it, as the living room isn’t a place where you can fully be by yourself.<n><n>### Answer Choice E<n>- Although the dog is only in the living room, and not the entire house, the dog still feels like it has all the room in the world to walk around. The dog doesn’t feel like it is limited to that space at all as it has to share the space with no one, so it is more like the dog’s personal space<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. Choices:  A: picnic B: friend's house C: table D: space shuttle E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: They were getting together for the Big Game, he wasn't Hosting but made sure to bring plenty of food with him over where?<n>My Response: He was bringing food to his friend's house<n><n>Answer Choice: C: <<Table>>table<n><n>My Response: The big game was a football game so he took plenty of food with him to his friend's home where he watched the big game.<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: How many times would someone have to fold them in the same place to use an 8.5’’ ruler as a paper towel?<n>Rationales<n><n><n>### Input<n><n><n>### Output<n> <n>### Output<n><n>### Task<n><n>### Solution<n><n><n>### Demand:Answer the following multiple answer question.<n>### Response:You could start anywhere on the map, but only start 5 minutes after the event of the start of the first race.<n>### Output<n>### Demand<n>### Response:If the first race is over at 2:55 (55 minutes after the start) you can begin the second race at 3:00 (5 after the first).<n><n>### Demarcation:<n><n>### 55<n><n>### 158<n><n>### 785<n><n>### Answer: 785<n>

Choices:  A: auditorium B: office C: synagogue D: confession E: church<n><n>### Response:		C is correct because synagogue is more of a religious place where people sit for prayer<n><n>### Rationales: Synagogues are used as places of worship for Jewish followers. A large meeting hall is known as a synagogue. Prayers are held in this location, and a large number of individuals gather to worship together. This suggests that synagogues are frequently occupied. Synagogues, on the other hand, are not restricted to one particular religion. A synagogue is not only used by Jewish followers of religion; rather, it is widely used. This means that not only do Jewish people use the synagogue, but also people of other religions, and thus a large number of people may be seen sitting in a synagogue. Thus, the answer is C.<n><n>### Input(Demonstration): What type of rock do people use the most for jewelry in North American and European style clothing? What should you do?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Given that a customer wants to buy at about 40 % discount, I would give it to her and take a discounted loss. <n>Then I can sell the other items to another customer at list price for a 10% discount. <n>My final net profit would be from that one item at a 30% discount.<n>#### 5 * 2 - 3 = 260.<n>The result is a negative number since the customers got a discount.<n>I would have a negative 260, in this case, if a customer paid only 204 dollars. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Glass that hasn't been treated to be extra strong is what? Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		Weak<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question and choose the correct answer from available options.<n><n>### Preparation: Click here to prepare your answer<n><n>### Demostration: <n>> Answer here!<n>

"))<n>        userResponse = input("answerYesQuestion: Yes/No? ")<n><n>        #if they say "no"<n>        if userResponse.lower() == 'no':<n>            print("No")<n><n>            return answerYesno<n><n>        else:<n>            #if it's not "no"<n><n>            #get the letter that was entered<n>            letter = userResponse[0]<n><n>            if letter == "y":<n>                letter = "yes"<n><n>                return answerYesTo<n><n>            elif letter == "n":<n>                letter = 'no"'<n>            else:

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:If I am a person, I have a unique ability to do what? Choices:  A: cross street B: stand upright C: speak spanish D: speak chinese E: further education<n><n>### Response:		 If I am a person, then I have the ability to cross the street.<n><n>### Input<n>Given a string str. What is the smallest possible sum of character’s values in str which results in the unique substring?<n>#### Answer:<n>A ->13 B ->17<n>C ->14 D ->16<n>E ->15    <n><n>## Challenge :<n>#### Input:What should the length of the smallest substring be.<n>[A -> 3][B -> 4] [C -> 6] [D -> 5]<n>[E -> 4]<n><n><n>### Challenge:<n>#### Output:length of the substring is 100<n><n>### Strategy:<n>#### First, I'll list out all the substring with lenght 1-30.<n>#### Then if the substring is one of the 5, I'll list length 15-30 because no combination (length 4-14) will give me a different substring.<n>#### Next, I'll list 1-30 but take away 5 from 15-39 so that I don't take more than 3 letters 1-2 times.<n>#### Finally, if anything remains and 5 is not a substring I'll take 5 and move to 10-19, and so on until it is the only substring.<n><n>```<n>string =  "ABCDEBCADEABDEABCEABBBAE"<n><n>length of substring[0]= 0 length of substring[1] = 2 length of substring[2] = 3 length of substring[3] = 4 length of substring[4] = 5 length of substring[5] = 6 length of substring[6] = 7 length of substring[7] = 8 length of substring[9] = 20 length of substring[5]= 11 length of substring[0]=13<n>```<n><n>## Rationale:<n>If there are 5 in the substring, then I can't remove letters, so I have to get 13-5=8 and list everything greater than 8 with my method, and if 5 is not a string then that means I have to go up to 19.<n><n>### Challenge Solution<n><n>1.  List out all substrings that have a length

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. Which is longer?<n><n>### Third response:<n>Total of 10 syllabals<n>1st: syallable: "is" 2nd: syallable: home 3rd: syallable of that 4th: syallable: use 5th: syallable "from" 6th: syallable the: second 7th: syallable : the 2nd one 8th: syallable 9th: syallable" the" 10th: syallable<n><n>### Input on this assignment is a list of 5 words. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Mom is tidying a house, where would she put the loose dictionary? Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Demnstraion:Mom has a dictionary and she's putting it away.<n><n>### Input:(Choose an answer that best describes your reaction.)<n><n>### I have no idea if this is a real homework problem or not, but here's what I do know. She's tidying so any loose book will end up on a bookshelf somewhere. She could make a library from something that was outdated or from books that kids borrow from. Since they're tidying so she might be using classroom books, which wouldn't be shelved at home. For desks, well you always have a dictionary next to it 📔<n><n>### Input (Choose an answer that is best from you.)<n>Mom is tidying in her home, so it wouldn't be a desk.<n><n>### Response (Choose an answer.)<n><n>### A<n><n>### <n><n>### Input Choice is:A <n><n>### Response Choice is:E <n><n>### Let's assume that both answers are right.<n><n>

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What do rich people like in terms of bagels? Choices:  A: poor B: sleepy C: plain D: needy E: homeless<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:In this case, multiple people and other types of animals can be placed in rooms in order to maximize the total utility within the space:<n><n>### Input:"How many animals can I keep in my room?"<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Room 1: 1 people, 2 dogs, 2 cats<n>Room 2: 2 people, 2 dogs<n>Room 3: 4 people, 2 cats, 3 dogs<n>Room 4: 3 people<n>Room 5: 7 people<n><n><n>#### 4<n>Answer:  How many people can i keep in my room?<n><n>### Insturctions:<n><n>### Demo:<n>In a house, there are 5 bedrooms: 1 bedroom has 2 sleep pods, 2 pods in another bedroom, and 4 pods in another bedrooms. A guest bedroom has 4 pillows: 2 large pillows, 2 medium pillows, and 4 small pillows.<n>There are 3 guest bedrooms that have 2 pillows and 8 guest bedrooms with 1 pillows.<n><n><n>#### 7103889669570899472032167893<n>Answer:  Guest bedrooms and sleep pods<n><n>### Insturections:<n><n>##|Demonstaction:<n>Lemonade = 6 mango = 5 orange = 3 lime = 4 lemon = 7 apple<n><n>##|Answer:<n>Mango + Apple<n><n>## Input:<n>How many different combinations can Mary and Steve pick out of their options if they pick a total of 88 books each?<n><n>## Demonstraction:<n><n>Mary = 19 books<n>Steve = 11 books<n><n>24, 11, 1, 5<n><n>#### 324<n>Answer: How many different combinations can Mary an Steve pick out of their books?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What might a person receive from their boss if they do a poor job? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		<n>Following is a correct answer.<n>A: frustration<n><n>### Analysis:<n>Following text is given:<n>- Bob and Boris were standing <n>- In a queue at the groceries store in line they were standing <n>- Fast but the children in front <n>- of them were loud out of order children were being annoyed to other people.<n><n>Hence the options to choose are(a) being annoyed(b) being delayed(d) irritation(c) out of the order.<n><n>### Question:What is 16-15?<n><n>### Answers:<n>Following answer is correct.<n>16-15 = <<16-15=1>> 1.<n><n>### Analysis :16 - 15=1 since 16 is less than 15.<n><n>### 25+4=<n><n>### Rationales:25+4=29<n><n>### <n><n>### How many pages in a book are 64% of the total pages?<n><n>### A: 63% B: 89% C : 94% D: 96% E: 98%<n><n>### Answer:94%<n>### Answers :94 % of the pages in the book.<n><n>### Input :Find the product of the following set of numbers?<n><n>### 4**14 =<n><n>### 11841152.<n>### Analysis:In the above expression 4 4,14 is repeated 1 time.hence the product will be the number multiplied by itself 1 time so the product will be 4**1.<n><n>## 25+4<n>## **25+4=** **29**.<n><n>## **29+4**<n>## **37**<n><n>##How can you change<n><n>## **69 to a number**<n><n>##within  range of **1-100** which adds up to **4**?<n><n>##Solution:<n><n>- 69 <n>- 69-1 =68 <n>- 68-2  = 66 <n>-. 66-2  = 0<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The child pounded his mitt in excitement while enjoying his first game in the bleachers where? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The spoiled child's playroom was massive, but only one of many rooms in the what? Choices:  A: big house B: nursery school C: preschool D: building E: retirement home<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rational:The sentence:the spoiled child's massive, but only one many room is describing a "big house" because a big house is a description of the house (the structure or building) while "many" refers to how many children live in the house. The big house is located in the what? There are many choices, however, a building is the most accurate answer (not a retirement home, because a retirement home will be much smaller) The last choice (nursery school) does not completely describe the answer.<n><n>### Input (Continued):<n>The "spoiled child's" is referring to the child and not the "big house." The child may be referring to his parents or him. "Spoiled" means that child is spoiled and this is referring to a child that is unhealthy.<n><n>### Rationale (Continued): <n>Since the child is spoiled, he or she must live in a big house.<n><n>### Answer: B<n>### Response: C<n><n>### Input the following three questions.<n><n>What do the following expressions have in common? <br><n>"There is a mouse." <br><n>"The mouse is in the house." <br><n><n>The common factor they share is "The mouse", which is the subject of the sentence.<n><n>### Question:<n>Which is an example of an idiom? <br><n>An elephant in the room <br><n><n>"An elephant in a room"" is used in a sentence when there's a problem, but it's never spoken about. An elephant in the middle of the room would cause a lot of talk. In contrast, the second definition may describe a big problem that a person might not be talking about.<n><n>https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/reading-retell/grammar/v/reading-critical-reasoning

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:An electronics store had things damaged from the rain, where should these things be stored? Choices:  A: large city B: strip mall C: building D: shopping mall E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Input Choices:<n><n>#### A:<n>#### B:<n>#### C:<n>#### D:<n>#### E:<n><n>### Demolition<n><n># Description:<n>The below are a sample of questions/examples of an exam for students who have taken the "Exam Demo."<n><n>### Instructions:<n>For each of the following examples, answer the questions fully with sentences and correctly identify one choice(s) of each choice with capital letters.<n><n>### Examples:<n><n>### Example:<n>Input:  The store was so busy that there was no parking space. <n>Choices:<n>* A: My wife was in line.<n>* B: My father-in-law called us.<n>* C: I had to go down town.<n>* D: My spouse was at home.<n>* E: My husband was at the gas station.<n><n>### Answer Example:<n>Answer: My father-in law called us.<n>### Explanation:<n>We must assume that the speaker has a wife, and my father-in law lives out of town and thus, could not be parking at the store.<n>Also, it was "us" not "me" that my father-in-law was calling.<n><n>### Example<n>Input:  She got her hair cut. <n>choices:<n>* A. on Friday<n>* B. yesterday<n>* C. on Thursday<n>* D. Saturday<n>* E. last month<n><n>### Answer<n>Answer: C. on Thursdays<n>Explanation: <n>If any of the other choices answered correctly, <n>a. I would need more information<n>b. a statement would be more clear.<n>### Example<n>Instruction: <n>She made a pie.<n>Write a response that properly fills in each of the blank(s).<n><n>### Example (blank)<n><n>Input:  She made ____, which used an apple and a pie.<n>Choices:<n>A: her own dessert<n>B: an apple pie<n>C: a pie<n>D: an apple pie<n><n>### Answer (blank)<n><n>Answer: An apple pie<n><n>## Sample Exam<n>This is an example of the level 1 exam.<n><n>## Practice<n>* Below is a multiple choice question with multiple responses
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What would release energy, but not mainly in your muscles? Choices:  A: vent B: think C: shouting D: work off E: exercise<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Rationale: Vents have a pressure, but are sealed, so the air is not expelled all at once. Therefore it does not mainly release in your muscles since the air is not moving outwardly.<n><n>### Input What can you not eat at home?<n>**The Answer:** Anything at home<n><n>### Rationale: Home is where you are suppose to be safe and eat anything.<n><n>### Output What do you know about food?<n>**Answer:** I know that food is an important thing to the human body. It is what makes your body do its main functions.<n><n>### Rationla: The word food means to eat and a food is something that is eaten that keeps you alive.<n><n>### Question:Why does your body's temperature change?<n>**Answer: Your body's temperature change because when your body shiver your body feels cold and because of this your body sweats.<n><n>### Why do people feel the cold more when they are wet?<n>**Answer: Why people feel the cold more because when you are wet and your body is sweating and feels cold.<n><n>### People feel the cold more when you're wet because when you sweat your body is cold and you feel cold.<n><n>## Task:<n>Your manager is considering installing a network, for which the following table shows the network topology: The total cost is $70,000. How many nodes does she need to install to achieve the lowest cost, with a minimum of 5 percent spared?<n><n>```html<n>+------+-----------+<n>| N     | Cost       |<n>+------+-----------+ |<n>|    5 | $  12,000  |<n>|    6 | $  13,500  |<n>+------+----------+-----      |<n>     |         |        ^<n>     N ----------4-------3|<n>     |      |         |<n>+------+----------+     5|<n>     |         |<n>N +-------------------+<n>```<n><n>### Question<n>How many nodes does your manager need to install to achieve a minimum of 5% spared?<n><n>### Inputs<n>```html<n>$70,00 - $12,00 - 13,50 - 12,00/2 = 3.5 - 3.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:He had a hard time finding the room on his schedule, it was on the second floor and he got lost in the very large what? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What happens when someone is playing too aggressively? Choices:  A: get hungry B: laughter C: injury D: having fun E: feeling happy<n><n>### Response:		Input:What happens when someone’s a little too aggressive? Choices:  D: feeling happy E: having fun<n><n>Output:When someone is being to aggressive, he may feel hungry or be injured.  However, he will most likely not be happy.  Rather, he may be injured and might laugh.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: D

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Someone who is awake is likely to know what's going on because they are this? Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Justify:The correct answer is D.<n><n>### The correct answer is D because someone who is awake is alert (alertness). While they may be a bit groggy or unfocused at first, this is only temporary and soon fades away after they get a few cups of coffee or tea.<n><n>### A: alert: Incorrect<n><n>#### Incorrect response: Alert or alertness refers to a condition involving attention, and the ability to respond quickly to something.<n><n>### B: deep sleep: Incorrect<n><n><n><n>Incorrect response: Deep sleep is 4 of the 5 stages of non-Rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep.<n><n>### C: drink coffee: Inconsistent<n><n>#### Consistent with correct answer: Consistent with correct answer because:<n>One gets alert after they drink some Coffee.<n><n>### D: open eyes: Inconsistent<n>#### Inconsistent with correct answer for the following reason:<n><n>#### False-Positives (Incorrect answers)<n><n>The question asks about someone who is awake, not whether they should be awake, which means they are awake. This makes Open eyes (Being Aware) and Conscious (Awake) incorrect.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:A water spout was seen in the ocean off the coast of what? Choices:  A: florida B: basement C: sink D: beach E: fountain<n><n>### Response:		E:Fountain<n><n>How to solve:The beach is a place where people swim and relax by the shoreline. It is surrounded by the sea. Therefore it cannot be the water spout observed on the ocean. The water spout is observed on the open ocean or a body of water that is very far from land. The body of water near the shore is the coast of the sea or the ocean and can be considered ocean.<n>The water spout cannot originate from a fountain because fountains on land flow straight downward, and cannot rise upwards from under water as it happens with water spouts.<n>The spout is like a siphon and does not have a mouth. Therefore it cannot be a sink or a basement.<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the four multiple-choice questions below each with a yes or no answer.<n><n>### Question:Which of the following statements is true in terms of numbers<n><n>### Choices:A. For all the n ≥ 0, |n| ≥ 0<n><n>### Answer:A:For all the n ≥ |n| ≥0<n><n>### Rationale:It is not true that for all the n ≥0, |n| = 0 or that for all the n >0, |n| > 0.<n>The number 0 is not a natural number so, we cannot replace |n| with n.<n><n>### Answer 2:For all the n >0, |n-4| = 0<n><n>##### Question:While counting from 1 to 100, which of the following statement is true?<n><n>### Choice:A. The number 33 is the number that comes after 32 in terms of counting<n><n>### Answer:(A):The number 33 is not the number that comes after<n>32 in terms of countering<n>Every number in between both 32 and 33 can be reached through a different path.<n><n>### Another statement:<n>The number 34 is the the number that comes before 35 in terms of countering.<n><n>### Rationales:The number 32 = 23 while 33 = 24. Therefore, 23 is not the number before in terms of counting while it is a number less that 33

Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n><n>### Response:		contaminated<n><n>### Why?<n>The lab assistant got the sample "________"<n><n>Rationales: <<punching bags>>punching bags<n>The sample needed to be ______________, but the lab assistant got ___________<n><n>#### <n><n>### Input- Output:  You enter the following program:<n><n>### Demonsration: <<a function that returns 4>>4<n><n>### Response to Demo:<n>The program displayed: 8.  The answer is << 2 * 4>>2.  The program failed to multiply by 2 in two places where it should.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>You enter a function that returns 4.  That is, 4 returns 4.  The program displays 8, because the program multiplies by 2 on every iteration.<n><n><n>### How to debug:<n><n>### Try changing the numbers in the program and seeing if they do what you expect.<n><n>### The most recent change made by the developer broke the program.<n><n>### What is the number that should have replaced 8 in >>x=8>>x=?  Why did the program break? How many x's do you see in the program?<n><n>### What did you do wrong in the program (indicated by the bug)? List your step by step approach for debugging the program.<n><n>#### The program should have returned 4.<n>The bug is located in the second return statement. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What do you need to have before buying products? Choices:  A: desire B: spending money C: money D: needs E: time<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answers: 1. need  2. C<n><n>### Input : Write a sentence that will not be true. Choices:  A. I want to eat steak. B. I want to eat pizza. C. I am hungry. D. I want to eat meat.<n><n>### Response :<n>Answers:1. False<n><n><n>### Instructions:The text below is a part of an informational article. Write a response for each numbered item.<n><n>### Text:The human heart pumps blood (flowing through the arteries) to all organs in your body, including the brain. The heart pumps between 5 and 6 quarts (about 5 liters) of blood every day. The pressure of your blood pushing against the walls of your blood vessels keeps you alive. The heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles. The left side of the heart performs one job: to supply blood to the lungs, and the right side of the heart performs two jobs: to receive oxygen-poor blood from the body and to send oxygen-rich blood to the body. The right side of the heart has 2 chambers: right atrium and right ventricle. During each heartbeat or pump, the right atrium sends blood to the right ventricle, which pumps blood through the pulmonary artery, to the lungs (to let the red blood cells absorb oxygen). The left atrium receives slightly beutier blood from the lungs, fills the left ventricle, which delivers the blood through the left pulmonary artery through the aorta, around the body.The heartbeat is controlled by electrical signals that travel in a special pathway called the electrical conduction system that starts in the sinoatrial node in the right atrium. These impulses travel through the atria to the AV node, then to the Bundle of His and finally to the ventricles. After each contraction, the heart relaxes and refills the heart chambers, forming another contraction.<n><n>#### 1.	Why are Mary’s ears ringing?<n><n>### Rationales : Mary ear is ringing because she is deaf and dumb.<n><n>#### 2.	True or false: Your heart beats 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What happens when humans are exposed to noises? Choices:  A: pet the dog B: hear sounds C: have sex D: reproduce E: drive cars<n><n>### Response:		Choice: B<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Choices: <n>A: age grieving person <n><n>The only thing in the question that affects the person's age is the stress of grieving a loss.<n>For this reason, the most plausible answer is 'A'<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>A-A grieving person can go through a lot of emotional stress and this can cause depression.Depression can be a form of stress and can have severe, deadly effects.<n>The fact that this question only talks about the age grieving a person and not the person is grieving about indicates that we should only consider the effects age can have on a person.<n>This is clearly the answer to the question, it's the only one that involves age.<n><n>---<n>

Choices:  A: cabinet B: computer printer C: suitcase D: office supply store E: artist's studio<n><n>### Response:		<n>(A) cabinet<n><n>### Explanation:Cabinets have larger pieces of wood as they are normally placed in a room that is furnished as a bedroom.<n>### Response:<n>(A) Cabinet<n><n>### Examples:<n>Cabinets normally house furniture, such as drawers, shelves, and cupboards. Cabinets have several different names: a piece of furniture with doors and shelves, a cabinet, a drawer or even a pantry. They range in size from small wardrobes to large pieces of furniture. The word cabinete comes from French. There are many different types of cabinets, such as the pantry, dresser, entertainment center, bathroom vanity, and bar cabinet.<n><n><n><n>A cabinet might have several different names, but cabinets also come in different sizes. They usually have a drawer, cabinet shelves, and drawers. They normally do not have cupboards.<n><n>### References:- https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8417100/where-can-i-reuse-pieces-of-paper-rather-than-using-printed-paper-for-an-artist#8417121

It has lost 2/5 of its limbs but is still upright. Why does the 6 meter tree need to be cut down?<n><n>## Rationales: A 6 meter tree would have a total length of 6*101=602 meters. It lost 2/5 which is <<2/5*6=3/5>>3/5 of its limps or <<3/5*6=1.8>>1.8 meter. However since 3 meters equals a meter, the tree lost <<1.8/3=0.6>>0.6/3 meters. The remaining 3/5 = <<3/5*3=1.5>> 1.5 meters is not enough to hold the tree up.<n><n>The tree is now <<2/5*0.6=0.4>> 0.4 meters.  It can be considered collapsed.  It is now unstable because it will not hold itself up.<n><n>Therefore, it has to be cut down.<n><n>#### 1.8<n><n>Answer: 1.8 meters.<n><n>### Input :Why would someone not want to compete in cross-country races with a team of professional athletes?<n><n><p>Choices: A: The cross country race is not fun B: Professionals are faster C: Professionals are stronger D: Professionals are slower E: They will not all fit.<n><n>### Answer: D<n><n>### Instuctions:Answer the following question.<n><n>## Rational:<n><p>Professionals are the best at their sport and are expected to be the most athletic and fastest. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The shore was now a tourist attraction with nearby little shops, but at one time this what was home to a bustling fishing industry? I made these choices to fit the description of the question.<n><n>\textbf{"The feeling of antipathy":} A feeling of intense aversion and often contempt for someone or something.<n><n>Since antipathy is the feeling and someone who doesn't care towards someone else can only feel the aversion towards that person or thing, then the question is answered.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: <n>

From the choices, I know that A, H, and D are incorrect. As for B, it seemed like the safest choice for the question, as the answer mentioned events, and malls were probably not the safest. For E, it didn't mention a "store", and sears doesn't specifically mention "sporting equipment", so I eliminated that from the choices. This meant it was more than likely to be either choices A or D. From the options shown, I noted that B mentioned sporting and that was what led me to guess C.<n><n>### Input : What is the next number in the series?<n>3, 9, 27, 81,?<n><n>### Response : 243<n><n>### Dated Explanation of why the answer is correct:<n>According to the question, a sequence that is given are 0 3 0 3 in a sequence of 0 3 3 0 0. Therefore the next number should be 3. The pattern seems to be going for even sequences on odd numbers and odd sequences on even numbers. The number 3 fits into this sequence, just with the wrong numbers. Therefore the next number on this sequence, should have been a number that is a pattern of 27. This would then mean that the answer should be 243.<n><n>### Output:How many minutes are in 15?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: How many minutes are in 48?<n>Rationales in the demo are not important, since this is a multiple choice question<n><n>The question is asking for the number of minutes in 48, which means that the answer is 48 / 60 which equals <<48/60=0.8>>0.8 minutes. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The mother finished wrapping the very last gift, she then placed it under the what? Choices:  A: department store B: fraizer fur C: specialty store D: christmas tree E: christmas stocking<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n><n>```js<n>function(s) {<n>  switch (s) {<n>    case "department store":<n>      return "A"<n>      break;<n>    case "fraizer fur":<n>      return "C"<n>      break;      <n>    case "specialty store":<n>      return  "D"<n>      break;                  <n>    case "christmas tree":<n>      return "E"<n>      break;        <n>  }<n>};<n>```<n><n><n>```js <n>function(s)  {<n>switch (s) {<n> case "A":<n>return "A"<n>break;<n>case "C":<n>return "C"<n>break;<n><n>case"D":<n>return "D"<n>break;<n>   case "E":<n>return "E"<n>break;<n>}<n>};<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: competition B: blood C: wins D: medals E: erections<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- Choice C: wins matches<n><n>### Justification:<n>The man was playfully wasting with a woman that the man was in love with and this is evidence the man was in love. Since blood was not mentioned it does not seem to be physiological. Since there is no medal or competition the best choice for the physiological result is A.<n><n>### Question<n>#### 3<n>Answer: Wins matches<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The small cabin was not available, so they were upgraded to what? Choices:  A: villa B: spacecraft C: hall D: palace E: hotel<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A: villa<n><n>#### 44

What was the best solution for the problem?  Choices:  A and 8 are identical.  B: The two solutions are not mathematically feasible.  C: The two solutions are mathematically feasible, based on all the available information.  D: The six solutions are mathematically feasbile, based on all the information available.  E: The two solutions are mathematicalfeasible, based on all of the information available.<n><n>### Rationale:The 8 students can be seated anywhere on the train, based on all the students’ preferences.  The only solution that includes all six students is having 6 groups on the train.  Since there’s no other feasible solution involving both 6 students and a minimum of 2 students per group, option C is the correct solution.<n><n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? Choices:  A: say thank B: smile C: looking for D: get more E: show appreciation<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer was A, B, or C. Your response should give a short, accurate answer.<n><n>### Rationale: Smiling and giving a "thank you" are both types of "saying thank you."<n><n>### Input<n>What is the greatest number you can make using the digits 3 and 7, and the value of the digits in this order?<n><n>### Options<n>37<n>Input:76543<n>Output:596084<n><n><n>### Demostration<n>Input:Enter a number<n>Output:a) the sum of all the digits in the number.b) the sum of all pairs of digits.c) the product of all numbers.d) the sum of all numbers<n><n><n><n><n><n>```python<n>from decimal import*<n>def power(x,y,m):<n>    return(pow(x,y,exp(1.0/m,x,m)) /pow(10,m) )<n><n><n>```<n>### Instruction<n>Input:Enter a positive number; you have six attempts. What is the greatest number that can be made when reading the digits in this order, 3 4 5 6 7 8?<n><n>### Demosation<n>#### 8<n>Answer:69<n><n><n>### <n><n>### 3.2.3 Input:Enter a number<n>```python<n>Input:Enter a negative number<n>Output:Which number, if added to the original number and then squared, produces the product of the two numbers?<n><n><n>```<n><n>### Input-87265<n>#### 8<n>Output:Enter a number<n>Input:What fraction of any positive number is the fraction 3/5?<n>Answer:10<n><n>```python<n>    def rational(n,rat): # to convert to rational<n>        return(int(rat[1])+(rat[0]*(int(rat[0]))) )<n>        <n>    def pfactor(n): # to multiply two rational frac.<n>        return rational( n, rational(n,p) * p )<n><n><n>    def cfactor(n): #to divide r. & c. fracs<n>        return rational(n, rational(10, 10) * p /(rat(n,p)) )
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Some might say that if you want to do something that results in changing society then you need to start from within, to do this what would you be doing? Choices:  A: riots B: vote C: change yourself D: social activism E: change clothes<n><n>### Response:		If you want to do something to change society you need to change yourself first by changing the society which means voting is the best because once you vote for the people you want in power you have already influenced the whole society which in turn will make your life better or change your life in a positive way!<n><n>### Demostration : If you want to do something you need to change yourself which means vote for the people who will make your life better then you have already changed the society and your life is also changed!<n><n>####<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:A shark swam in the background aquarium as the card players sat emotionless, what were they playing? Give examples of when using the second would make more sense.<n><n>####  Difference: <n><n>#### First Program:<n><n>#### Second Program<n><n>#### Explanation:<n>I just copied everything out of his program and renamed his types as he did, I added 2 lines I will explain and comment on:<n><n>```C++<n>using namespace std;<n>class A { A(int); int a; public: int a; };<n>class B { B(int, int); A a; };<n>int main() { B aB(3); aB.a.a=4; printf("%d\n",aB.a.a); }<n>```<n><n>The first line is just a line that shows that it is a using namespace std;<n>We rename the class A using names and change the name of the variable to a.<n>Next, We use the keyword using namespace std, <n>The keyword B (B is our new name), We added (int, int) to the class definition.<n>The next line is the same thing we did before, we are adding and passing in 3 as an integer to the constructor function (3)<n>The last line is very important in my opinion, it prints out 4, this is so we can write our second program and it will print something out, we do this by using the variable in the class definition (3) and it has been declared as an int.<n><n>#### Explanations:<n>The second class definition was really hard to do at first but now that I understand how things work I am not afraid! It is a really simple way to do things.<n>The way I chose to do it is rename the classes and add the parameter as the second to last line. This way we can use both class types.<n>The way he did it was really smart and
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where did the compassionate farmer allow the heifer to reside during her last days? Choices:  A: cattle ranch B: countryside C: grocery store D: slaughterhouse E: dairy farm<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Rationale:The heifers were not intended to be sold for meat in a slaughterhouse. They were intended to be sold in a dairy farm and a grocery store only. Since the compassionate rancher kept the heifers alive and well, he did not allow the heifers to reside in either a slaughterhouse or a grocery store. This means he kept them in his dairy farm or on the countryside where they can live peacefully until they become older cows.<n><n>#### <mark>4</mark><n><n>### Input :Where did the compassiona farmer allow the heifers reside during their last days? A: cattle ranch. B: countrysi de. C: grocery s tore D: sp aughter hou se. E: dairy farm 😎 <n><n>### Response : B<n><n>### Rat ionlae:Th e heifers are not intended to be sold in the slaughterhouse for meat because the compassionate  farmer was just kind and tender to all his animals. In  other words,the farmer does not really like watching the animals suffer. He does not like the smell of blood and the sight of the animals crying in anguish in the farmer's slaughterhouse.  Conversely, the grocery store does not sell animals; it only sells and packages them for people intending to feed their animals in their own houses at home. Therefore, the cows will just roam and wander about the countryside peacefully. Likewise, the heifers live in the farmer  dairy farm because they belong there - as they are supposed to be raised for dairy products. Their kind treatment and compassion makes them the best choice for food products, such as cream, butter, and milk.

All objects should be events.<n>2. Both objects should contain the same event type.<n>3. Both objects' year should be the same.<n>   * Events such as: "1960s", "Brazilian car accident," "1961," are not comparable because they are not events.<n>   * World Series should be compared to World Series and not NHL playoff series.<n>   * The year for an event can be "1986" or "1980-1982" and is valid.<n>   * Multiple events from the same year should be able to be compared to each other.<n>   * The name of an event is required to be compared.<n>4. If two objects have all of the above compared, and match, they are similar.<n>   * World War II (1940-1946) and the Cuban Missile Crisis (1962) are similar.<n>   */<n><n>// The above code tests whether `x` is comparable to `y`. If they are, it sets `ret`<n>// to `true`, or to `false` otherwise. The below function uses `ret` to indicate a<n>// value instead of `true` or `false`.<n>function y(x) {<n>  return ret(x, y)<n>}<n><n>// `ret()`<n>function ret(x, y, z) {<n>  if(!(x.date === y.date && x.event === y.event &&<n>        z.event)) {<n>    return false<n>  }<n>}<n><n>var x = {"event":"Bulls vs. Blazers","date":"May 1993"}<n>y(x);        // returns x.event == Bulls vs.. Blazers (1993), x.date == May 1993<n>                 // returns x..event == Bull

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where should an excavation never take place? Choices:  A: construction site B: cemetary C: building D: city E: archeological site<n><n>### Response:		 Building<n>Directions: Input: Write the correct choice for each question. <n>If the choice is “X”, just write “X”.<n>If the choice is some other answer, write an answer, followed by the letter of the answer. <n><n>#### D: X<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Reaching advantage position in a competitin puts me in what position as compared to others? Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### D) higher position<n><n>### Answer:<n>* 5 choices are there in this question.<n><n>* First choice is 'A' that means determination.<n>* Second choice is 'B' that means upper hand.<n>* Third choice is 'C' that means superior.<n>* Fourth choice is 'E' that means skill.<n><n>* So if our choices are in between 'D': determination and 'E': skill then the answer will be same and it is 'E': skill.<n><n>* The correct answer is 'E': Skill<n><n>### Instructions For Task: Below are details about a job opening that can be filled by a candidate with the appropriate experience and educational background.<n><n>### Input 1: <n><n>#### What is the total number of people in the office? Choice A: 12 people B: 120 people C: 75 people D: 10 people E: 3 people<n><n>#### Total - 12 + 15 = 27<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n># Instruction: The numbers in the parentheses are answers to questions. In a step, the number in parentheses is subtracted from the number in the previous step to find the next correct answer.<n><n>#Instructions: Write the responses that complete the steps.<n><n>  Below is an example of a simple computer program. Write the final response to each sequence of instructions and explain your answer. You may need to perform a subtraction or division. Input numbers using single-quote marks (‘ ).<n>Input: x = 5 //5<n>y = 4 //4<n>z = z + (x - y) //19<n><n><n>#Answer<n><n>Final Answer: 19<n><n>#Explanation<n><n>### Input1:5 x 4 = 20 -6=14 -4 =10<n><n>### Input2: y = 4 //4 (Substract 4 from y which = 4+4=8->y) -->Next value of Y ==8<n><n>### Input3: z = z + (5-8) //9 (Substract 5 -8=7- =7)<n><n>### FinalAnswer==9+7=16<n><n>### Answer==16<n><n>## <n><n>#### In this question, write a response

Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def checkAnswer(answer):<n>    if (answer == 'grocery' or answer == 'C'):<n>        return "A"<n>    if answer == None:<n>        return "D"<n>    if answer in ['a', 'b']:<n>        return "E"<n>    elif answer =='street':<n>        return "B"<n>    <n>    else:<n>        return "C"<n><n>answer = input().split()<n>if checkAnswer(answer):   <n>        pass<n>else:<n>    print()<n>    print()<n>```<n>#### None<n>#### grocery shop<n>#### cross street<n>#### feel happy<n>#### shout at<n>#### A<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? Choices:  A: water B: liquid C: foamy D: intoxicating E: harmful<n><n>### Response:		<n>Its not right A it should be liquid, which is a solution. Cause it flows. <n> <n><n>### Inputs: 12 students.<n>What is the total number of students?<n><n>### Demostrarions: <n><n>How many students does not sum up to 12 since there are 12 students in total.<n><n> ### Output:<n><n> ### Answer: 12<n>### How Many Apples?<n><n>Input: 7 students had apples. 4 of them had 4 apples each. 2 of them had 3 apples each. 1 student had 2 apples.<n><n>How many apples were shared?<n>### Response: <n>### Demonstracion:<n>There were 4 apples for each student. 4x4=4 then 3 students had 3 apples= 3x3=9 then 2 apples for one=2. In total there are 15 apples. 15 apples were shared.<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where does a beaver leave? Choices: <n><n>#### <n>If it's in a body of water.<n>If not, tell the user how you know that.<n>####<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input<n><n>Where does a fish live in the water?<n>Choices: <n><n>### Response<n>If it's a river, tell the user how the water flow affects the fish.<n>Otherwise, tell the user how humans affect the fish.<n>####<n>Answer<n><n>###Input<n>How does it feel when you jump? Great Relief has nothing to do with feelings at all and is an adjective that relates to physical action rather than a state of mind. Isolation means "cut off," not feel better.<n>Absolution is an intercession - not a state of mind.<n>It is also a common phrase, "I forgive you," not a feeling.<n>#### <n><n>### Input 2:What is 50% of an answer question? The area of that triangle would then be equal to the area of the base*height^2 = <<area*height>><n>The key then would be to understand that a triangles area is made up of two areas: one half of the base and one half of the height * the height, in which case the area is, <<base*half hight* height>><n>For a given triangle of area, the height and the base can be changed, but changing the area of the triangle is more difficult.<n><n>### Input<n><n>This problem requires a mathematical formula to divide by an odd digit number.<n><n>Output: 1002 / 7 = 142<n><n>### Input This problem requires a mathematical formula: 1000/5 * 2 = 440 to subtract a number from a decimal number.<n><n>Output 440 - 0.2 = 439.8<n><n>### Instructions:<n> 1. Answer the following multiple choice question:<n>    a)<n><n> 2. Now describe a task that includes these steps:<n><n><n>### Instructor’s note:<n><n><n>This answer is based on the following formula for area:  ‘A=1/2 * b1 * h’<n>1/2 is the area, b1 is both the base and also the height, and therefore the height*height would equal the area<n>

The statement contains the verb "build". The prepositional phrase which contains that verb is the subject, The beaver, the object of construction.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>####  a. books.<n>The beaver builds structures to Block Books.<n><n>####  b. zoo.<n>The beaver Builds structures to Block Zoos.<n><n>####  c. body of water.<n>The beaver Buisness blocks Water. (in this case water could represent a body of water)<n><n>####  d. wooded area.<n>The beaver Blocks Wooded are areas.<n><n>####  e. animals.<n>The beaver Buils structures to block animals.<n><n>### 44<n><n>Answer: 8 of the 12 choices listed here do not include the word block in the prepositional phrase containing the verb builds. The only statements which include that word and match the prepositional phrase in the statement are<n>```<n>B Books<n>C Blocks of water<n>D Blocked wooded areas<n>D Blocked animals<n>```

What is John’s role if John is a shift manager for a single location, but works with another location in the chain for the day, so they can cover each other's shifts?<n><n>### Response :  A shift manager can have more than one restaurant location in his or her job responsibilities.  John can cross-train in shift management for both locations.<n><n>### Input<n><n>How many of the following words cannot be made using ‘a,’ ‘b,’ ‘c,’ and ‘f’?<n><n>A. AFC<n>B. BBC<n>C. AFE<n>D. ABC<n><n>Answers: C<n><n>### Input A clock has hands made of 26-inch wooden rods. How much more time will it take for every clock cycle if the clock’s speed is doubled?<n>### Answer A: 1:40<n><n>```<n>1:40 divided by 30 = 1:40/30 = 4/30 *1:30 = 7:15:30 =<n>5 x 15 minute hour = 15 minute x 3 = 45 minute =<n>3600/45 = 80<n>```<n><n>### Input When you throw a pingpong ball against a 2-foot-high wall, it bounces back after 0.03 second.  How fast is the ball moving when it hits the wall?<n>A. 0.1 mph<n>B. 0.8 mph<n>C. 15 mph<n>D. 25 mph<n><n>Answer: C<n><n>1600 = 6 x 240<n><n>Dividing by 240: 1600/240 = 6<n><n>1 second = 60 mph<n><n>### Input Where are there a large number of pulsars?
