Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		How often is the secular party held?<n><n>#### A,Ans:Answer:Frequent.<n><n>### Input:-1 = A. -2 = B. 0 = C. 1 = D. 2 = E. <n><n>### Response:-1-1 = A. -1-2 = B. -2-0 = D. 1-1 = C. 2-0 = E. <n>Rationales:<n><n>1. To subtract -1 and -1, you only had to subtract -2.<n>2. -2 and -2 = 0<n>3. -2 and -1 = 1<n>4. -2 and 0 = -2<n><n>### Input<n>>A = A<n>>B = 1<n>>C = 2<n>>D = -1<n>>E - D. = + 3<n><n>### response:D+3=A<n>Rationales:1+3=4<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following in complete sentences.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input:<n><n>><n><n>### Response<n>A=500<n>Ans=600<n><n>### Instructioin:An equation may have multiple answers if the numbers involved are ambiguous. Write a response that describes the ambiguity and specifies clearly which of four possible answers may be the correct answer.<n><n>1. 49 / 72 = A.Ans: <30 / 60 = 0><n>2. 45 + 22 = A.Ana: <45+5 = 50><n>3. 2 + 25 = A.Ana <45+5,50+10,60> <n>### Demo<n>4.<n>### Instructon: An equation may have multiple answers<n>### Demo: Input: -1 + 35 = A. Ans: 37.<n>### Instrucion: If there are ambiguous numbers, a single equation with many answers<n>### Demo<n>Input: <14 + 15 = A. Ans = 17.><n><n>### Input.Input: -16 5 * 4 / 12. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer is D) sameness.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>We expect to find the word "same" in the definition. We can substitute values anywhere between two numbers.<n>If you go from 2 to 4, their sum will be 6, their difference will be 4.<n>If you go between 8 to 10, their sum will be the same as their difference.<n>This relationship is true any time we start with one number and go to another number.<n>Answer B is likeness. There is no word for likeness in the given definition.<n>We can't say "more alike".<n>Answer C is alike. There is no word that states the whole range between 1 and 4 is alike.<n><n>### Bonus Input:<n>What does the term <i>"the number of things differing from the first"</i> mean in the above definition?<n><n>### Bonuses Explanation:<n>Answer A: Difference. This is the only term in the definition.<n>Answer B: N (No difference here).<n><n>### Bonusexplanation2:<n>The second answer is D. (0 is a number).<n><n>### RationaleExplanation:<n>The rationale was, that the number of things differing between two numbers is the same as what the difference between them is.<n>As a definition of a difference, it says that the amount of things between two numbers is the difference between the numbers.<n><n>### Further questions:<n>### Input:<n>What is the difference between this situation and the previous one?<n><n>### Expectation:<n>There are a total of 8 differences, not 4.<n><n>### Response<n>A: There are a total of 16 items. They start out with 2. Then there are 4 different items, and they go up in each one by two, so they go up from 2 to 3 to 4 to 5. They go up by 2 each time.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>B: They only move up by 2.<n>C: They only move in even numbers.<n>The only difference between A and B is, they only go up in odd numbers after going up in 2.<n>The only difference is they only go up in even numbers.<n><n>## BonusExplanation:<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a theater which only has unpaid actors? Choices:  A: shopping mall B: hospitals C: populated area D: school E: military base<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer:C, populated area.<n><n>### Detaisl:<n><n>```python<n><n># 📱 Input<n>answer_phone_no = raw_input("What is the telephone number of the party you are calling?")<n># print answer_phone_no<n><n># ✅ Output<n>if raw_input("This is a test to see if the phone number is valid. Can you hear me?") in answer_phone_no:<n>    print "The phone is valid"<n>else:<n>    print "I didn't get a valid response from that phone number."<n><n>    <n><n># ✌ Output<n># [x] A test has been given to see if the phone was valid. Can you hear what I'm saying?<n># [ ] A test has been given. Can you hear what they're saying?<n># [x] I am on the air.<n><n><n># ┏━━━━━━┳━━━━━<n># [ ]   Can you hear me OK?<n>┗━━━━━ζ━━━━━ <n># A. The answer does not make sense. Can you hear me OK.<n># B. "Helloooo! Did you get that? If not, I repeat: Can you hear me?"<n># C. "Helloooo, this is 1-42! Did you get that?"<n># D. "Hellooo 1-42, this is 91"<n># E. "Hellooo! Did you get what I said? I repeat: Can you get me 911?"<n><n><n><n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:She wanted to make a quilt of velvet, where should she look? Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### 44

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The man needed to buy flooring, where was he looking for it? Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The only possible options are A and B. Both A and B have a "home" prefix.<n><n><n>### Answer:<n>A<n><n>### Input:(Select 2:  (4)(4)(4)(7) + (3)(6)(11) + (8)(9)(12) + (5)(8)<n>### Input:<n>Choose 2 integers using *<n><n>### Demosntration:<n>The correct answer has to be the sum of 2 numbers which we can use * to get them.<n><n><n>## Input:<n><n>The two numbers you choose don’t matter because the sum doesn’t depend on them.<n><n>### Answer to the demonstration<n><n><n>The answer is <<(4)(4)(4) + (3)(3)(11) +(5)(5)(12) +(8)(8)(9)>><n><<4 * 4 * 4 + 3 * 3 * 11 + 5*5*12 + 8*8*9>><n><n>128 + 129 + 148 + 849 = <<128+129+148+849>><n><n>### Rationales<n><n>The answer to any sum of the form **a* * b* c*, where * is any operation, is equal to a + b + c regardless of which two numbers you choose.<n><n>## Answer:<n><n>128+100<n><n><n><n>## <n>```python<n>answer = 128+160<n>answer = 142<n>```<n>## Input:<n>Choose any 3 numbers that sum to 24<n><n>## Demonstration: (answer = 17, so answer should be <<17>><n><n>### Answer<n><n>The answer is ((9)(6)(1), which sums to 5, added to ((7)(3)(2) which sums to 14, added to ((5)(4)(3) which sums to 4, which is what you want)<n><n><n>```python<n>answer=24+((9)(6)(1)+((7)(3)(2)+((5)(4)(4))<n>answer=6<n>```<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The person turned the oven on and put a pizza in, what happened one hour later? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n>Since you're not looking directly at the cup, how would you know?  You couldn't tell what the material it's on or even its dimensions unless you examine it or have experienced it before.<n><n>### Answer 1:<n>The man lacked the skill because he didn't do anything to it or add the cup on anything.  He just let it be out as it is.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The man didn't do anything with this cup.  So there were no what to balance it? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		The right answer is letter C cabinet.<n><n>### Input and rationale: The answer choices are as follows:<n><n>-   A: radio shack – is not correct.<n><n>-   B: substation – is not correct.  A substation is not something that is usually in your home.<n><n>-   C: cabinet – is correct.  A cabinet is a place to put your entertainment equipment (e.g. radio, television, video, etc.).<n><n>-   D: television – is not correct. Your TV does not require cable. It requires electricity or an antenna.<n><n>-   E: desk – is not correct. A desk is a place to put paper, pen, etc.  It is not a place to put your TV.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What state south of Kentucky and north of Alabama will you find people playing the fiddle? Choices:  A: alabama B: tennessee C: violin case D: music store E: bow and strings<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C) tennessee<n><n>#### Answer:<n><n>_D:_ music store<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that demonstrates the correct way to create a new function in JavaScript.<n><n>### Challenge:<n>For each of the functions below, write out a call that demonstrates using the new function.<n><n>```js<n>function sum(x, y) {<n>  return (x + y);<n>}<n>function mult(x, y) => {<n>  return (y * x);<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>_calling_sum(),<n><n>_calling sum_mult(2,3),<n><n>### Answer:<n>Sum: 17, Mult: 6.<n>

Write the sentence as it appears in the question and then write the new sentence.<n><n>### Input :I want to buy a car that get a lot of miles on it.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### Rationales:  I want to buy a car <<car1>> that get a lot of mile on it <<car2>>. <n><n>#### Miles and Mile<n>Answer:  That Get a Lot of Miles on it.<n><n>#### Mile and Eye<n>Answer:  That gets a lot of mile on me.<n> <n>### Input: What kind of sport is played in both the winter olympics and the world cup? E: snowboarding.<n><n>### Description<n><n>We can use the same procedure for any word problem, not just ones where you need to add and/or subtract.  Notice how the answer we gave for the multiplication problem was the same as the example problem given by the instruction.  This is because 44 is what was given in the example, but if I had written, 66, for my response, it would have been correct as well.  We can do the same type of procedure for division and addition as well.<n><n>### References<n><n>-https://www.educationspecialist.com/blogs/entry/how-to-solve-multi-step-math-problems<n>-http://www.mathstutor.com/free_math_help/explanation_of_how_to_solve_simple_math_problems_part_of_i_want_to_buy_a_car<n><n>### Quality Assessment<n><n>The Quality Assessment section is designed to help you think through and develop critical thinking skills about the quality and usefulness of the work you submit.  It is an important practice tool for learning not only the skills assessed by the instructor but the habits and strategies needed for you to assess quality when working on your own.

Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>#### Rationale: Stanley has trouble telling this dream from reality because it was a very vivid dream that contained things that only happened in his dreams.<n><n>### Input:(4,2) A: a 45-foot long train  B: a 35-foot long train   C: an 86-mile train  D: a 80-mile train  E: a 55-foot long train<n><n>### Response:(A)<n><n>#### Solution:<n>The longer the train, the longer the train. <n> 45-foot > 86-mile > 35-foot > 55-foot <n><n>45ft>86mi>35ft>55ft<n><n><n>### Input : 87(4): 4.27(1) 4.85(1) 5.09(3) B: 9.02(1) C: 7.01(2) D: 4.38(1) E: 4.23(2)<n><n>### Response :E<n><n>#### Solution :<n><n>```python<n>    def factorial(n):<n>        temp=1<n>        for i in range(1,n+1):<n>            temp = temp*i<n>        return temp<n>    a=4<n>    b=87<n>    x=factorial(b)<n>    print(a*x)<n>```<n>#### Test:<n>python<n>1010101<n><n>### Input  : (5, 4) A: 4.09 B: 3.89 C: 5.98 D: 2.37 E: 4.79<n><n>### Response  : B<n><n>#### Rationale<n>`2^(4096) = 4.09E-81`<n><n>### Input::  (8, 4) A B C D E<n><n>### Response::B<n><n>####Rationale<n>`32 ^2 = 1024 <8*4=32 < 1024`<n><n>### Instructions::Ask the question: Who lives in London? <n><n>### Demostration::London is a city in the United Kingdom,

Choices:  A: jerusalem B: jewish community C: middle east D: city E: mosque<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are famous temples all over the world, but none more famous than The Vatican. The Vatican is a tiny piece of land, 110 acres to be precise, that houses many monuments, including the Saint Peter's Basilica, the Sistine Chapel, St.Peter's Cathedral, and a few palaces. The Vatican has more than 100 museums, galleries and tapestries, and is the official residence of the Pope.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Which of the following is the name of the capital of Ireland? Choices: A. Belfast B. Dublin C. Dublin D. Belfast E. Dublin F. Dublin G. Dublin H. Dublin I. Dublin J. Dublin K. Dublin L. Dublin M. Dublin N. Dublin O. Dublin P. Dublin Q. Dublin R. Dublin S. Dublin T. Dublin U. Dublin V. Dublin W. Dublin X. Dublin Y. Dublin Z. Dublin A. Belfast Dublin Dublin Dublin Dublin Dublin Dublin<n><n>### Response 2:<n>While Ireland has 9 official capitals within its six counties, Dublin, the largest of the nine cities, is the capital city where most of their government operations occur.<n><n>### Explanation 2:<n>Ireland has 9 official cities, all of which are in one of six counties. 6 of the cities are counties of their own. The other three are in counties of greater Dublin.  Outside of Dublin, there are three cities in the larger county of Dublin; one of these is the governmental center for Ireland's central government.  The cities of Limerick and Galway are the other two independent cities within the county that contain Dublin.<n><n>![](./resources/images/challenge-2/45-46.jpg)<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Sally lost her kite because she wasn't careful. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. The example given is a reduction of a quantity where a value is lost in a specific quantity. The value of an apple could be defined as the cost of the apple where 10 apples x 0.30$ = <<10 x.30=3.00>>3.00, but the number of apples available after three apples have been lost would be 10 - 3 = <<10-3=7>>7, where 7 is the number of remaining apples after 3 fell off.<n><n>### Test:<n>Input: 7 caterpillars are crawling on a branch.  2 caterpillars fall off the branch. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where are there more telephone booths? Choices:  A: gas stations B: city C: london D: train station E: airport<n><n>### Response:		The answer we have right now is A.<n><n>*Gas stations:<n><n>- The gas stations all require one phone booth.<n><n>- The train station has a phone booth<n><n>- And the airport has a phone booth (in a large building with a number of other facilities)<n><n>We have a choice of B, C and D.<n><n>- The london city has its own phone booth<n><n>* The london train station has a phonebooth (in the bigger building)<n>- And city has a phonebooth in every 1 km radius.<n><n>The number of phonebooths in the London train station and london city is the same (<<Gas stations:1>>).<n><n>However, London train station is in the london city district, so the same phonebooths serve both districts.<n><n>In all, there are twice as many phonebooths in london as the next most numerous city: the london train station (<<Gas stations:(1*3)=3>>).<n><n>Therefore, A is always the correct answer.<n><n>(A) A gas stop station has one in front and a lot of phone booths.<n><n>(B) Cities have more phone booths than anywhere else in the world. <n><n>(C) London is the capital and most populous city of England.<n><n>(D) Many train stations have a phone booth next to a large and empty room. <n><n>#### (E) There are fewer phone booths at airports, but more are located in London.<n><n>Answer: london<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>A customer complained that he is not fully satisfied with the quality of the product. Each question has only one correct answer.<n><n>Each answer must be an integer from 1 to 6.<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: The numbers are increasing in a straight line. There seems to be a trend and a slope. At what point will there be only 5 integers and the slope will equal its original state.<n><n>Answer: 6<n>Rationales: All 5 integers will be 1,2,3,4 or 5<n>At the 5 integer point, we have that n = 6<n>The slope will equal n + 1 because there is no point that has more than 1 increment.<n><n>2<n>The slope will equal 0 because we can only have 1 or 2 numbers that are on the same line for a point. But that means a slope of 1 because when a slope is 0, it is a vertical line where the line goes up and down straight<n><n>Answer: 5.5<n>The slope will equal the square root of (n) because that means it is doubling half of the time and halving the other half of the time. We only have that because n = 6 has the square root of 6 = 2 (2x2 = 4). We then go down half-way from where we are so we have (5.5).<n><n>Answer. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input 2<n><n>Sir Edward wrote a book where he analyzed the works of 7 authors. The work was completed in 24 months. The authors he wrote about were John, Linda E, Jane, Mark, and Charles each of whom took 15 days to answer each question from the book. If the first author took 5 hours to complete his task and wrote and responded to Sir Edward on the first day, and Sir Edward spent 4 more hours in editing and formatting, what was the total time required to complete the task?<n><n>### Answer<n>635 hours<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>Sir Edward took 24 months to complete the work.<n><n>In 24 months, there are 86,400 seconds in a day.<n><n>So, there were 86,440,000 seconds in a year.<n><n>From the 86,420,000 minutes, let us round-off to 87,000,000<n><n>Took 24 months, hence there are 84 weeks (1 week=6 days) <n><n>1 week * 60 minutes/hour=60 minutes<n><n>87,007,200 minutes in a quarter year( 1/2 of a year) <n><n>Let us round-off to next nearest integer i.e. 87008,000 minutes or <n><n>1438 days<n><n>So, 84 weeks of 1438 days taken to complete the work, or we can say,<n><n>24 months of 1437 workdays <n><n>We also have the number of days in a week, let us keep that as well.<n>Sir Edward spent 4 hours editing and formatting each day i.e. he spent 72 hours in two days. Hence, if sir Edward was to complete 4 hour on a day, how much will it take to complete the work in a day to a week.<n><n>If the first author took 15 days as an average, for 8400 days taken to complete the total project,<n><n>It took the first 2 days(87000,080 seconds or 15.81 min)<n><n>It took the second

Choices:  A: accompaniment to meal B: waitress C: cafeteria D: home E: menu<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The choices that are in BOLD are the ones that give the most clues to the answer. <n><n>A) Is an accompaniment to a meal and this meal is a main course. A glass of milk would be an accompaniment to this main course.<n><n>B) Waitress would be to tell a waitress, to call to the waitress for a <n> <n>C) Cafeteria could mean that you want to buy the milk at the cafe.<n><n>D) Home can mean home delivery where you would call and they could<n> <n>E) This choice is correct because the only clue that is in BOLD of the items above is the word menu. A menu can be a listing of items like food at a restaurant, so you can find out if they serve milk if you can read the menu. <n><n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input<n>John has to build a rectangular cabinet but does not have enough wood.  After the rectangular cabinet and wood he has been given, how wide is the cabinet?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer: <<Length=5*width>>5*12=60cm<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>To figure out how wide the cabinet is, all you need to know is the area of 12cm by using the formula A=L*W.<n><n>This means you will first need to figure out the length using the dimensions that it is provided.<n><n>The length is used to find the area. To find the area simply multiply the length times the width and the answer will be your area.<n><n>```javascript<n>area = L * W<n>= 26*12<n>= 312cm  <n>```<n><n>Once you figure out the dimensions all you need to do is apply the formula for the area.<n><n>```<n>area = 2*L*W<n>= 2*(26*12)<n>= 524cm<n>```<n><n>The answer is 524 cm.

Peter had 13 stickers.  He used 5 large stickers on the cover page, then he chose 5 small stickers to use on 5 other pages.  What number of stickers does Peter have left?<n>Rationales:(1) Peter used 5 large stickes + 5 small stickers on the 5 other pages = <<5+5=10>><<big+other>>*number of pages = <<10>*<<5>>10 small stickers.<n><n>(2) Peter had a total of 13 stickers, so now he has has 13-10 = <<13-10=3>>3 stickers left.<n><n>#### 60<n>Answer: 60 / D: amusement park<n><n>### Input <n>How many animals are in the animal group that has 12 birds and 3 turtles and 4 frogs and 5 cats and 2 dogs and 1 elephant?<n><n>#### 64<n>Answer: 64 / D: amusement parrk

How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where will a bullet projectile be found during a war? Choices:  A: morning person B: early bird C: lark D: early riser E: rooster<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Rationale:<n>A night owl head can also describe what you'd hear at sunset, so A is not correct. <n><n>E is not correct due to the sunrise/sunset relationship.<n>C is incorrect due to the sleep cycle, roosters crow as the sun begins to rise.<n>D is not correct as being an early riser is not a bird.<n>Correct choice: B<n><n>### Input The temperature in Celsius is twice that in Fahrenheit. Is the Fahrenheit temperature hotter than the Celsius temperature, or is the Celsius temperature hotter than the Fahrenheit temperature?<n><n>### Rationales:<n>- Hotter than the Fahrenhert is incorrect since the answer is 2 times hotter.<n>- Hotter than than the Celsius is true since Fahrenheit and Celsius both have the same unit and thus the Celsius is hotter than the Fahreenth.<n>- The opposite true is false since 2 times hotter is not two units hotter.

How might she come off? Choices:  A: cold B: unfamiliar C: unknown D: unacquainted E: shy<n><n>### Response:		<n>A person who is shy may appear to be cold, but a person who is cold may not necessarily be shy. <n>The question seems to be asking how Mary may appear to be to James.<n>A. a person who is shy : She may come off to him as cold because she is shy.<n>B. a person who is cold : She may come off cold because she is cold.<n>C. a person who is unknown : She can come off as cold because she is unknown to him, but it doesn't seem to imply shyness.<n>D. a person who is unacquainted : Her behavior may come off as unfamiliar to him.<n>E. a person who is uncertain : Her behavior may seem to come off as uncomfortable to James.<n>#### The best answer is: Unknown<n><n>### Answer:<n>A person who was unacquainted may appear to James as unacquainted/unfamiliar/cold, but  James will need to see whether Mary "comes off" cold or unacquainted.<n><n>### Input:(1) How long was he/she there?<n>(2) Where did he/she go?<n>#### (3) What happened there?<n><n>### Demogrp (1) How long was she there?<n><n>#### 2) She went home(3) She wasn't at the library for long. <n><n>### Explanation:(4) He hadn't met her. =>(5) He didn't see what happened there<n><n>------<n><n>|<n>-[How long did she stay at the library?<n>-Where did she go when she  returned?<n>-Did she notice what happened there?]<n>-He was a teacher who taught her in Grade 5. You will take note of the definition of the word given under the word of the day title. Then, you will be asked a question to elicit how the word in the word of the day was used in the short stories. You are supposed to identify the context of that word in the particular short stories.<n>When you first learn English, you know very few words. So you often use a single word in many ways.<n>Writers, however, know thousands of English words, and they often use each word in different contexts.<n>As you learn English, you will become more aware of this subtleties of language.<n><n><n>#### What happened to the conscience of someone caught committing a murder (question 1)? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:How might people perceive someone they are scared of? Choices:  A: human B: happy C: dangerous D: strange E: weird<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### human B: happy C. dangerous D: strange E. weird<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What often happens after a long day of traveling? Choices:  A: sickness B: motion sickness C: relocation D: jet lag E: fatigue<n><n>### Response:		I: <n>### Explanation:<n>```<n>Input:What often happens after an hour of traveling?<n><n>Choices:  A: hunger B: dizziness C: thirst D: sleepiness E: fatigue<n>```<n>#### 43<n>Answer: 43<n><n>### Input<n>What are the two words that are most likely to be found in a grocery store?<n><n>### Answer:<n>A: I: <n>B: <n>C:  << 7 * 43*99 + 47*101>>769<n><n>### Explanatory question: <n><n>### Instructions:Use the following information to answer the questions below in addition to the 6.01 in Section 1.A to determine how many times each word has been found.<n>For example, if the word 'pot' had been found once in the text, A. Pot B. Potatoes, and C. Potato Juice, the answer would be 3.<n><n>Number of times the word was found in the text: 116<n><n>#### Which of these words occur once, twice, or three times in the text?A: <<1*24*91 >>245<n>**Explanatory questions and instructions:**<n><n>### Instructio:What are the two words A. Potatoes B. Potato that are most likely to found often in a grocery?<n><n>### Explanaiton:A: <<7*89*765 >><<517>>517<n><n>### Instuction:<n>What is the sum of the number of letters and the number of words in the text?<n><n><n>#### 37<n>Answer:43<n><n>## Input:How many times does the word 'potatoes' appear in the following text?<n><n>## Explanation:A: <<7 * 28 * 68 >>612<n><n>## Output:565<n><n>## Input:<n>How many times does the text contain each of the following five words?<n>A. A balloon store sells balloons  not balloons <n><n>### Correct answer is 4: Table.<n><n>### Answers is: Balloon Store, Table<n><n>#### Balloon is the object the person/subject is trying to find.<n><n>#### Store is the place they are trying to find it at<n><n>#### Table is the place the object will be placed at<n><n>#### A Balon store is the subject. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The movie had many a song and dance, it was a what? Choices:  A: bollywood B: record C: musical D: jukebox E: napster<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### 1)<n>**A**<n><n>***Incorrect***<n>The movie had many a songs and dances. It was a musical. No bollywood, record, or jukebox involved. <n><n>### Credits<n>Inspiration from https://github.com/HackerRank/test-cases/issues/358<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Many containers full of goods are unloaded where after their long sea journey Choices:  A: port B: cargo ship C: refrigerator D: food E: lorry<n><n>### Response:		In this question we are only given the choices which relate to the correct answer. I assume that the port (A) would be the container full of goods, which is "unloaded" (that is opened to discharge its contents) at its destination, while the refrigerator (E) would be the vehicle "full of goods" being transported from the port to its destination, and so the food in those goods' containers would be unloaded "where" (here) it would be in the cargo ship (B).  <n><n>### Response summary:<n>#### Input: Mary had 80 stickers.  She uses 3 large stickers/page on the cover page of the journal and 7 sticking pages each to 6 other  pages of the journal. How many sticking pages does Mary have remaining???                                                                                                           2.Input: A carload of tires is lost where after the journey   Choices:  A- the harbor in port B- the ship, C- the truck, D- the warehouse, E- the store.<n><n>### Response : The "carload" of tires is lost on the harbor (and not a "ship").<n><n>### Input A: It was a good morning for Jim which had no worries,  not even the slightest one since he had planned everything thoroughly.  He was happy and enjoyed the ride<n><n>### Response A: I had planned everything thoroughly. (This sentence is about Jim, but the verbs that refer to him are in the plural).<n><n>### Input B: It was a good time for Jim which had no concerns,  not even the remotest one since he had pre-planned the entire route. He was cheerful and enjoyed the entire ride<n><n>### Consequences B: I pre-planned the route (This sentence is about Sam, but the verbs are in the singular.<n><n>### Input C: It was a pleasant morning for Jim which had not even the slightest concern since he had planned everything beforehand. He was cheerful in the company of his friends and enjoyed the entire ride,<n><n>Consequences A: He felt all the better.<n><n>### Conclusion A:<n>

The length of the boom arm is related to the length of the microphone and the audio waves.<n>Recent stock market events such as the financial crisis of 2020 or the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic of 2022 have led to more people listening to coverage of the stock market from home. TV news hosts may hold microphones with long boom arms to direct audio to an audience.<n><n>### Input:"The president said yesterday that this year's budget surplus would be around 500 trillion dollars." Sometimes there are multiple names for one person. Write a for loop to identify the number of letters in the name John. Remember to indent each loop iteration and use the label ‘for‘ at the start of the loop.<n><n>### Response.Write an if statement.<n><n>### Rationales: An if statement is a statement that evaluates a conditional and determines whether to execute one block of code or another.<n><n>### If the test of the conditional is true, the programmer’s statement will be executed. If the test of the if statement is false, a different statement might be executed instead.<n><n>Input: Create an if statement to evaluate whether a person has more than 6 letters in their name.<n><n>#### 2a<n>Response: An if statement that evaluates how old a person is based on their age can be formed by using a condition within an if statement. Write an ‘if-else if' statement that will return the text “Young” if the program evaluates a condition below 13 and return the text “Adult” if 13 or older. Remember to indent each of the following blocks of code and use the label ‘if‘ at the start of each.<n><n>### 3 Instruction:<n><n>### Instructions.<n>Write an if statement to evaluate the height of a person. If the height of the person is less than 5 feet, the program should return the string “short”. If the height of a person is at least 5 feet, the message should say “ tall”. Remember to indent each of these blocks of code. Each statement must only check the height, do not check the other age variables.<n><n>### Example: <n><n>#### 3 Instructions:<n><n>### Response to multiple choice question.<n>The rationale is that you need to write a series of if statements that check the conditions as defined in the multiple choice question.<n> <n>### Example: The rationale is that a person is tall if the height is greater than 5

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where is a telephone booth likely to be red? Choices:  A: airport B: gotham city C: london D: city E: gas stations<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The correct reason is “city/business with cell phones.”<n>The incorrect reasons are “gas stations” and “gotham city.”<n>Even large cities like Paris and London have telephone booths.<n><n>### Input 2:How many different pairs of socks can you wear if you have 3 pairs of socks with 9 socks in each pair?<n><n>### Response 2:<n>The answer is 3.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>### Inputs:<n>You have two socks, then four socks, then six socks:<n>- 2: A green shrek sock and a yellow bob the builder sock<n>- 4: A lime green yoda sock,<n>- 6: A gray star wars sock,<n>-  8:A teal kermit sock,<n>-10: A neon pink pikachu sock,<n>-	14: A dark purple cinderella sock,<n>-22: A royal blue mickey mouse sock<n>-44: A grey spongebob sock,<n>-88: A black batman sock,<n>-0: A white bob the builder socks<n><n>### Rationals: <n>You start with two pairs, 4, 6, 8, 10, 14, 22, 44, 88<n>44 + 88 = 132 socks.<n>We started with 132, now we are dividing by 6 since there are 6 socks in each of the six pairs:<n>132 / 6 = 22 socks/6 socks.<n>Thus, there are 32 socks leftover which means you started with 110 socks in the first place!<n><n>### Input :What is less than 1/3 and more than -1/9? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Sally was a senior in the House.  What might she be a member of? Choices:  A: assisted living facility B: old people's home C: high school or college D: republican party E: organization<n><n>### Response:		F: house<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Sally was a senior, which means a senior in a high school or in college. Hence, the choices A,B,D don't work. C is not a correct answer, as seniors are generally over the age of 65. Since a person, who's over the age of 18 is called an adult in some countries. Houses are, most of the time, not living places for seniors: <<Houses>>are called as [[[housemaid]]]. So, F is the correct answer.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Sally was born in ______________ in 1994.<n>A: August C: May B: December D: July<n>E: February<n><n>### Rationale<n>Sally was born on August 08, 1994, since her birthday is in August, the month is C. August, December, February and July is not an option for choice.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>```<n>A: <Select an option><n>C: December<n>B: July<n>E: January<n>D: August<n>```<n><n>### Choice C: December<n><n>### Choose A: <Select an option>.<n><n>### Choices: A: July<n><n>### Raison: July is not an option.<n><n>### Chooses: D: August<n><n>### Raisins: August are not options.<n><n><n># MLO-4<n><n>### Writing a task statement:<n><n>Write a request that appropriately completes this task.<n><n>### Additional Requirements: <n>- Write in either a first person, or third person tone<n>- Use the following format for your request:<n>```<n><S:> The S: has {M:} amount of {T:}. They can make  it to where the S has  <J:>.  Let them get {T:}.<n>```<n>- Be precise and concise<n>- Make sure that everything they said is complete<n>### Input:<n><S:>The S: has 51 bags amount of marbles. They can make it to where the S gets 167.</S:><n><n>### Response<n>- The S: <S> has 51 baggage amount of marbles. 
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:John lives in Texas. If he takes the highway South and doesn't stop, where will he end up next? Choices:  A: oklahoma B: developed land C: united states D: desert E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B - developed <n><n>### Explanation<n>It's not possible to have a drive south and not go to another state, but since we dont know what John will eat or use, any choice to stop means that we do not know how to drive south correctly. Also, we don't know what he is doing if he is driving, but just because we dont know what John is doing doesnt mean that we dont know which direction he is driving<n><n>#### 8<n><n>### Input John lives in Florida. If he took the 128 highway North and didn't stop, where would he end up next?  Choices: A: FL B: developed land C D: oklahoma E: united <n><n>### Response<n>We know John likes to go to states that are developed and dont like the desert and don't want to go to the mexico side just yet. we know that there is a desert between florida and the next developed state, which could be texas. he would have to stop in texas, because the route doesnt go that far into texas to not stop, so that leaves us with oklahoma. John lives in Florida, and doesnt like the developed land, but he likes developing land.<n><n>#### 16<n><n>### Input What is the average temperature difference in the southern hemisphere compared to the northern hemisphere, in degrees Celsius?<n><n>### Response <n>22.75 degrees Celcius in the southern part of the world is always cooler than the temperature in the northern part of the world, compared to the temperature in the southern part of southern temperatures (since they are at the poles).<n><n>#### 30<n><n>### Instructions: Below is a description of an activity. Which model would you buy?<n><n>### Demostration<n><n>The model that costs $0 and prints 1 inch is the model that costs $0.  You will never spend money on this printer, so save your $150!<n><n>#### 32<n><n>## <n>###

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:No matter the background of the person, they should all be given what in applying for the job? Choices:  A: critical thinking B: congratulated C: equal opportunity D: compliments E: raffle tickets<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>## Suggested Solutions:<n><div style="overflow-x: auto;"><n><table style="border: 1pt solid rgba(0, 0, 0,.8); padding: 32px; margin: 30px; background: #f3f6f9;"><n><tr style="border: 0.5px solid rgba(0,0,0,.75); padding: 30px"><n>  <td style="flex: auto; margin-left: 32px">Code: </td><n>  <td style="" id="code_cell" rowspan="2"><n>```ruby<n># (input) How many stickers does M have after using 3 large stickers?<n>p = Proc.new{3}<n># (input) What's the answer to the puzzle: Mary has 9 stickers left.<n>a = Puzzle::Prep.new.call('Mary had 89 stick')<n>answer = case a['stickers']<n>when 89<n>  '19'<n>when 88<n>  '21'<n>when 87<n>  '22'<n>when 58<n>  '20'<n>else<n>end<n>```<n>  </td><n></tr><n><tr style="background: #f6e9e7"><n> <td style="border: 3px solid rgba(0,.6,.8,.5)">Input: Mary had 58 stickers. How many stickers did Mary have before she used 3 large stickrs?</td><n> <td style="flex-wrap: wrap"> <n> <p>Mary has 58 stickers before she uses 3 big stickers. She uses 3 big stickrs on the front page of a journal (so she has 19 less stickers left).</p><n> <pre id="code_cell_1"></pre> <n> <p>19 = 19 - 22 = 22 - 22 = -5 =? </p><n> <p>Answer is 5 stickers</p><n> </td><n> <td aria-hidden="true" style="border: 4px solid rgb(255, 25
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What happens to the next appointment when a grooming takes longer than expected? Choices:  A: injury B: beauty C: late D: mistakes E: annoyed<n><n>### Response:		 D<n>#### D<n>Answer:  D<n><n>### Input<n><n>What did you have for breakfast?<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Breakfast<n>I ate eggs, pancakes and orange juice.<n><n>#### Eggs<n><n>#### Orange Juice<n><n>### Input (1)<n>How much did a computer cost?<n><n>### Demostration<n>The answer is that the answer is $3,339.00.<n><n>#### $3339<n>Answer: $3339.04<n><n>### input (2)<n>The computer was a MacBook pro.<n><n>### Response (3)<n>The price of the computer was $3,335.78.<n><n>### Inputs (4)<n>This computer had four cameras and a microphone.<n><n>### Rationals (5)<n>There were four cameras and one microphone on the computer.<n><n>### Answer (6)<n>The camera and the microphone were free.<n><n>#### 6<n>Answer: 63<n><n>### Instructions (7)<n>What was the first number in the word<n>“Nine Hundred Twenty Nine Thousand Five Hundred Twenty Ninth”?<n><n>#### 929<n>Answer: 929<n><n>### A, B, C, D<n><n>### A: What color is the sky?<n>It is blue.<n><n>#### Blue<n><n>###  B: How many colors do you have on your shirt?<n>One blue and a red. <n><n>#### Red<n><n>###  C:  What color is the grass?<n>Green<n><n>#### Green<n><n>###  D: What does rain look like?<n>Black-and-white.<n><n>#### Black And White<n><n>### D<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### 1<n>Let’s talk about 1.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer:0<n><n>### Input(2)<n>Let’s go to the zoo.<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer:3<n><n>### Input 1 (5)<n>The first day was full of animals.<n><n>####3<n>Answer:3

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Where would you stand in a line and need a coat if it is cold? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:where do you typically find a trash can in the city? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Sarah thought that she had been home all evening. Choices:  A: early morning B: day time C: night D: afternoon E: daytime<n><n>### Response:		<n>**If Sarah felt like her stay was long, her answer would be afternoon.** The only times she can leave at are: early morning, day time, night, and afternoon. These are the only four possibilities because it is either not "day time" or not "night" to have been home all night. The only time she is sure she is home is "early morning".<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. What might have to be delayed? Choices:  A: bookstore B: building C: meeting D: office E: coffeehouse<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Demostration:It is possible that all of the choices except for E might be delayed. Since this choice is specific to where all the delays occur, the choice is E.<n><n>### Explanation:There could be a variety of delays due to the amount of people or other scenarios.<n><n>However, it is specified that there weren't enough seats, so the choice is specific to where there is a delay. It is impossible to delay the bookstores, as they obviously weren't the places that needed it. It's equally impossible to delay the office, meeting or coffee house, as everything else is listed before it. So what is left? The building, and we can now easily eliminate everything but for the building. From there, it's not about what we cannot delay, it's about what we can.<n><n>As we can tell from the choices there are also only two choices left, so no other two need to be combined (the building, the meeting place, etc.). If we combine the building and the coffee house, we can eliminate the coffee house from being the choice that is delayed. From here we can cross-out all the other options, leaving us with only the building, and it is now clear choice E is the only option.<n><n>**What happened?**<n><n>**Eliminations**<n><n>**2**  <n>A, B, C<n><n>**1**  <n>E<n><n>![](https://github.com/MatthewWW/LyndaCoursesFall2020/blob/master/LearningProjects/MachineLearningforHumanity/2020-10-11%2016.10.19.png?raw=true)<n><n><n>### Excluding the second option and going with the first, there is only one option left for the 4th one as well now, and only 4 options left as a whole.<n><n>**5**  <n>D<n><n>**4**  <n>E<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What preposition do you use if you want to combine two words? Choices:  A: article B: adjective C: interjection D: conjunction E: pronoun<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C: Conjunction<n><n>### Comments:<n>A conjunction word joins two sentences together such as 'but' and 'or' or 'although'.<n><n>For example, 'I am hungry and tired' uses the conjunction 'and'.<n><n>Another example, 'Although I have a lot to do, I am still going to cook dinner for my friends'. In this sentence, the conjunction is the word 'although'.<n>

Choices: 1: The Police 2: The Go-Go’s 3: Peter Pan 4: The Flamingos 5: The Raveonettes<n><n>### Response :121:<n>#### 1: 2:<n><n>### Explanation:<n>```<n>The question is:Who is your favorite band?.<n><n>In the question,the speaker is asking you something. <n>Choices 1:The Police and Choices 2:The Go-Go’s are acceptable answers the choice <n>of the listener will either make you sad or happy based on their answer. <n><n>Choices 3:Peter Pan, 4:The Flamingos are acceptable answers <n>the choice of the listener will either make <n>you sad or happy based on the answer. <n><n>While Choices 5:The Raveonettes will certainly make you happy.<n><n>So  we can conclude that Choices 5 is the best answer.<n>```<n>

If 6 people got 1 donut for doing a good job, how many people got 0?<n><n>### Instructions<n><n><n>You need to choose the correct answer from a limited set of options.<n><n>**Solution**<n><n>12÷6+6==<12÷6=2>==<2×6=12>==<12×0=0><n><n><n>### Demostration<n><n>####  0<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Sample Answer - D<n><n>7 people got donuts for doing a<n>good job. Multiply 4 and 2<n><n>### Sample Instruction:<n><n><n>You need t choose the correct answer from limited set of choices.<n><n>How many of the following statements are true? She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What is the result of instituting civil action? Choices:  A: bad feelings B: confusion C: going to court D: hurt feelings E: sandwiches<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Rationale:E<n><n>## Question 2<n><n>### What does John do for the remaining weeks before he graduates college?<n><n>John spends 8 fewer hours every week preparing.<n><n>### Rationales: John is a college student; when he is a student, he doesn't need to make sandwiches for a living.<n>He spends 8 fewer weeks preparing for the summer job, until he graduates college.<n><n>### Input<n>How long is it? Input/ Output<n><n>### Question:In order to have a long life, Jack must eat 10 apples, have enough calcium, and work out for 40 minutes three times a day. Is that a fair trade? Choices A-F<n><n>I choose f:  Yes, those are all healthy practices<n><n>### Rationale:I chose f because they are all things that should and will lead to a long, healthy life<n><n><n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What is something that you feel when you go to the opera? Choices:  A: fall asleep B: headache C: boredom D: relaxation E: sick<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>####  D: relaxation<n><n>I think opera is a fun thing to do because there are many fun songs performed. Also, the orchestra, choir and soloist have great job of creating this wonderful music. They must practiced a lot on the performance, so they do their best in singing and playing the music.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>The orchestra is important because they provide the music, and they are the core of the opera since opera music depends on them. Choirs can help to bring out the voice that supports the orchestra. The soloist are also very important, and a lot of time they are people who sing really well.<n><n>### Input from the teacher or peer:<n><n>####  A:fall asleep<n><n>As I listen to the opera (it is like a long opera show), I sometimes feel a little bit bored, but I am not fall asleep.<n><n>####  D and A:relaxation<n><n>I feel relaxed when I go to the opera. At night, I want to go to sleep quickly, but instead I listen to the opera and fall asleep right away.<n><n>####  B:headache<n><n>If I had a headache, the opera may give it away because I cannot understand the plot. Also, if the music is too loud, I cannot appreciate the music because of that reason.<n><n>####  E:Sick<n><n>The opera is a performance, but it is live and it is not a movie. If you go to watch a live performance, you must feel healthy. You do not want to be sick when you want to have the best experience from the live performance.<n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:A school is most likely to be located in what sort of zone? Choices:  A: residential neighborhood B: community C: building D: prague E: every city<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Supporting Evidence:<n><n>### Demographer<n><n>### Data collection:<n><n>### Population study:<n><n>####  A: Residential neighborhood<n><n>### Community, neighborhood, city, municipality  <n><n>A community is a geographically localized group with more or less the same interests or activities, a common boundary, and usually a name<n>A city is a human settlement. Cities generally have substantial numbers of people, buildings, and infrastructure spread over a fairly large area, and are generally smaller than a town within city walls.<n><n>The data that we are collecting tells us that there should be no need to go back a second time to get more data.<n><n>### Population density:<n><n>Population density (PD), the number of people per unit of distance, refers to not the total number of people in an area, but how many are per unit of area. It is calculated by dividing the number of people in a given area by the total land area of the region.<n><n>### Question:How do you determine population density?<n><n>### Data density:<n>Data density measures the information rate of a transmission channel relative to the available system bandwidth or channel bandwidth,<n>and relates to the quality of a communications link. Data density is the amount of data transported per use of channel bandwidth.<n><n>### Data-Governed<n><n>### Data driven:<n>Data-driven refers to a practice, or system, that is guided by data to inform decision-making. Data-driven approaches support problem-solving by analyzing known information.<n><n>### Response-driven<n><n>### Relevant information<n>The following information are relevant <n><n>><n>### Conclusive statements

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Food must be freeze dried before it is taken on what vehicle? Choices:  A: fairgrounds B: friend's house C: space shuttle D: oven E: microwave<n><n>### Response:		<n>```C<n>Input:Food must be fresh dried before it is take in <your pick>.<n>```<n><n><n>

She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. wallflower<n>- Answer: A. wallflower<n>  "Standing Still"? is Correct for the choices "A: dance like crazy"<n>  "Wallflower" is Correct for the choices" B: standing still"<n>  "Progressively"???<n>  "Standing still"?<n>  "Like C: wallflower"?<n>  "Like Wallflower"? = "Dancing"<n>  "Walling Flower"?<n>  "Wall Flower"? = "Dancing"?<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The term "Progressively" is not in the set of possible choices.<n><n>### <n><n>### Input:"Gary is eating his dinner. He starts with 16 chicken drumsticks. He eats 5 chicken drumsticks each time he eats dinner. He eats dinner progressively because 5 is the average number of drumsticks he eats each time.  Gary ate all of the drumsticks last night. How many chicken drumsticks did Gary eat? "<n><n><n>### Response:"Gary ate <<16/5=3>>88 drumsticks.  (3 x 8=24) + (5 x 5=25) + (5 x4=20) + (5 x3=15) + 5= 90 drumsticks."<n><n><n>### Examples:<n>  - 89<n>  - 88<n>  - 24<n>  - 25<n>  - 20<n>  - 15<n>  - 90<n><n><n>#### Answer:88<n><n><n>#### 88<n>Answer: 88<n>Answer2:88 = True<n><n><n>### Input"A man has 3 chili dogs for lunch.  Afterwards, he realizes he cannot afford to buy one more chili dog. He cannot afford to eat the remaining two chili dogs at home later. How many chili dogs does he have remaining?<n><n>### Response"2 chili dogs"<n><n><n>### Rationale:<n>He had 3 in his lunch.<n>After having 3 in his lunc, he cannot afford to buy to add 1 more to his stash.<n>He cannot afford to eat the 2 he has
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What does someone living life fully feel? They only rise up in what sort of spaces? Choices:  A: population B: populated area C: create government D: group of people E: make person sick<n><n>### Response:		Choice: A<n><n>### Demosration:  <n>Society cannot exist(meaning without)without numbers.<n><n>```text<n>So:    Society cannot exist without numbers<n>     Society cannot exist without   <<without numbers>>0 numbers<n>     Society cannot    <<exist without>>0 exist <n>      Society cannot    <<exist>>0    exist <n>      Society      <<exist>>0      exist<n>      Society   <<exist>>0        exist<n>      Society            exist<n>```<n><n><n>### Output:  Society cannot exist  without 2 numbers<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Socrates said Society can not exist without numbers. Below is an instruction that describes a task. She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What do all rooms facing outside have? Choices:  A: square shape B: different sizes C: flowers D: doors and windows E: high walls<n><n>### Response:		<n>The response is below:<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Demonstration:<n>If multiple choice is C, then the choice that is different from all other rooms must be E. E is definitely not A. <n>A is a shape and it is not  a room. <n>So that leaves B, C and D. <n>You subtract the two choices that are not E from E => C<n>Then E = A*B<n><n>Thus the only choice that remains is D<n><n>#### Answer:<n>B<n><n>#### C<n><n>#### D<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Instructon:<n>Which of these is a real number?<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>\[4.81234805666679856524431,\frac{3+4}{7},[4.8133772040781617806321]+[3.40544825527484522978865],(-405488043),888661878904045293482018\]<n><n>\[(-8357)7.8107475123456157575,\frac{3+(-4)}{7},[-4.813448203359606186155293]+[-3.4059482334627103757881],00018099548709732974\]<n><n>\[-6.9411256313900624241,\frac{3-4}{7},[-8.42522835536779904425886]+[3.0637312960794644039467],00168384368751818393\]<n><n>\[25
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What usually happens to people who are models? Choices:  A: very ugly B: appear beautiful C: free slaves D: pay bills E: suffering pain<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Explanation:<n><n>A:very ugly->C.Free slaves<n><n>B:appear beautiful->E.Suffering pain<n><n>C:free slaves->A.Very ugly<n><n>D:pay bills->B.Appear beautiful<n><n>E:suffering pain->D.Pay bills<n><n>So the correct answer is E.Suffering pain.<n><n>---<n><n>## Answer Key<n><n>Answer: E. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Why would someone be wet after being full of fear? Choices:  A: run B: swimming C: calculate things quickly D: fight enemy E: urinate<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Rationales:The person full of fear usually has high adrenaline level that causes sweat.<n><n>#### A<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Input:(i) The name of the game is Moneyball.(ii) They use a computer system to do it.<n><n>### Response:(i) The computer is the game.(ii) The name of the program is Money Ball, the system uses to determine the success rates of a baseball team as well as the cost of each player.(iii) Baseball team have to decide how much money to spend each year and how much to budget for it. A player can make the team a winning ball club if his projected rate of return on every $100,000 invested in him is greater than 4%.(iv) This data was entered into the spreadsheet by the coaches.<n><n>#### (i)The name of the program is Baseball Analyst Software. The use of baseball game is baseball analytics.<n><n>#### The name of the program:Moneyball (i)<n>Answer:The name of the program: Moneyball (ii)<n>Answer:The system uses to determine the performance of the baseball team (iii)<n>Answer:The amount invested money on baseball player each season (iv)<n>Answer:This data was entered by the coaches who are hired by the baseball teams.<n><n>### Input:"Diligent in the management of his affairs," said Mrs. Auld.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>#### "His affairs" is a noun phrase. "in the management" is an embedded phrase.<n><n>#### "Diligent in the manager" is an adjective phrase<n><n>#### "in the management"  is a noun phrase and not an embedded phrase.<n>####(i)  "His affairs," is a noun phrase which is a modifier of "diligent".<n><n>####"Diligent in the manage," is an adverb phrase, which function is to serve as an adjective to modify<n>"diligent"<n>      <n>####"'diligent in the manage of his affairs," is a nonsense phrase.<n><n>####(ii) "Diligent in," is an adverb that describes the noun "in"<n><n>####"In the management" is a noun that modifies "diligent"<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:Dan outfitted his house to run on the oldest heat source on Earth. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:James was delayed for a couple of hours because he had a connection.  Where might his connection be? Choices:  A: company B: airport C: wall D: computer network E: love<n><n>### Response:		<n>James does have love, but the connection could be either of the other options.<n><n>### Output:<n>Response of Mary<n><n>1. Input: Mary had 297 stickers. She used 6 large stickers on the cover of her journal and 3 stickers each to 5 other pages of her journal, how many stickers does she have remaining?<n>2. Input: James was delayed for a couple hours, because he had a connection with company.Where might his connection be? A: Company B: Airport C: Wall D: Computer network E:  Love<n><n><n>3.Output:Response of Mary<n>Rationales:Mary added 3 stickers * 5 pages=<<3*5=15>>15 stickers to the 5 other pages. In total, Mary added 6 large stickers + 15 stickers = <<6+15=21>>21 stickers to her journal, since she started with 297 sticker, she now has 297 - 21 = <<297-21=276>>276 stickers left.<n><n>**4.Output:Response of James**<n><n>Rational: James does have love, but  connection could be either of other options.<n><n>**5.Output:Response of Maria**<n><n>Rationales:  **Maria**  has two choices, one  can be wall the  other can be computer network<n><n>### Solution:<n>`Inputs:Mary had 89 sticklers..`<n><n>There were three large stickers on front, and 7 stickers on each to 6 pages, so there are `7*6=46` stickers on those pages, and we start with 89 stickler, therefore remaining is `89-46=43`<n><n>`Inputs:James was delayed...`<n>- love<n>  - connection<n><n>This could be an connection with company, and computer network<n><n>`Mary:15 remaining`<n><n>`James:46 remaining`<n><n>So the final question should be asked in the form of comparison not an choice with different answers:<n><n>Mary had 83 stickler after addition, do you think James had more or less?<n>

Choices:  A: hang in closet B: sniff C: get dirty D: become soiled E: air out<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Sniff the clothes and sniff your socks to see if the odor is really from the clothing!  Do not dump the clothes into the hamper and hope they will smell better.<n>Launder clothes that still have odor as soon as possible. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Mary had 89 stickers.  She used 3 large stickers on the front page of her journal and 7 stickers each to 6 other pages of her journal. How many stickers does Mary have remaining?<n>Rationales: Mary added a total of 7 stickers/page * 6 pages= <<7*6=42>>42 stickers to the 6 other pages.<n>In total, Mary added 3 large stickers + 42 stickers = <<3+42=45>>45 stickers to her journal.<n>Since she started with 89 stickers, she now has 89 - 45 = <<89-45=44>>44 stickers left.<n>#### 44<n>Answer: 44<n><n>### Input:What might the inability to learn cause? Choices:  A: intelligence B: education C: effectiveness D: distress E: a stupid<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>B<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Distress is a psychological state.<n>Distress can be related to the inability to learn.<n><n>#### E<n><n>\[{\displaystyle \begin{aligned}\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \phantom{+} & \phantom{0+0+00}\end{aligned}}\]<n><n><n>### Input1:<n>What might the inability cause?<n><n>### Instructions1:<n>While we have the answers to all of the questions, choose a single personality type and go through each question and find ways it is true for that person, or if it is not, come up with an example.<n><n>### Input2:<n><n>\[{\begin{aligned}\qquad& \phantom{0+} \qquad\qquad A.
